Already getting an error from this basic test, that needs to be fixed before this PR goes in.
org.apache.kafka.streams.errors.StreamsException: Could not create internal topics.
	at org.apache.kafka.streams.processor.internals.InternalTopicManager.makeReady(InternalTopicManager.java:69). Looks like this might not be a real error though, since the replication factor of the internal topics is not maintained. Adding another broker and re-testing.

retest this please

@mjsax @ijuma My intuition is that, in jenkins `testNo:0` is not necessarily always runs to complete before `testNo:1` starts, and hence the issue. So I'd expect the fix in line "131" itself is sufficient? Not sure if the other changes would help here since they are guaranteed to be executed for each run anyways (but I think it is better to try/catch on each line as proposed in this PR as in `BeforeClass`).

I think it's better to use `@Before` to make sure we get a clean start for the second test. `@BeforeClass` should only be executed once and thus, the first test might "pollute" the second one, if we don't delete and re-create the topics.

@jozi-k Sorry for the late replies.

What I meant is that we recommend contributors to have one PR for a specific issue (i.e. as described in the corresponding JIRA ticket), more incremental PRs for a single JIRA ticket if it is a rather big feature addition; in addition, if more minor issues were found while working on the JIRA, it is recommended to propose those changes in a separate PR (you can create another branch besides your current working branch, for example). This is mainly for the ease of reviewing and separate different logical changes to avoid mental context switches for reviewers:

https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes

As for your current PR, to me it seems few of them are directly related to the issue described in KAFKA-1610 (i.e. making a pass in the code for any variables resulted in `mapValues` and make sure there is no further modifications to them) besides some code cleanups; on the other hand there are a bunch of fixes  that seems irrelevant to this specific ticket, e.g. `adding toMap to make sure they are immutable after filling up the map`, which I think would better be in a separate JIRA; similarly for the TODO markers you proposed in the JIRA, I'd suggest making them as separate PRs as well.

Does this sounds reasonable to you? Apologies if such guidances were not communicated earlier in time.
LGTM and the failure is unrelated. I'll fix up the typo during commit.

Note: This also fixes the checkstyle failure in `ResetIntegrationTest`

@guozhangwang, @mjsax, @miguno, @enothereska - seeing as we re-use state stores across rebalances they should be closed by the Processor. 

As a follow up to this we might want to consider how we can prevent the user from calling `close` from a `Processor`

Huge props for making the error message and doc output include the right description. Current situation is very misleading.

Few comments:
1. The new CLI is exposing what looks to me like an internal method to users. I'm all pro helping discovery, but this may need a mailing list discussion / vote. @ewencp?
2. It will be nice to add few words about the new CLI to docs/connect.html. There's currently literally no description on what this does, how to use it, etc.
3. Can you post a sample output of the log messages in the JIRA, so people can see "before/after"?

Other than that, the change looks small and safe so +1, pending the possible short KIP for the new CLI and adding the docs. I'll also be happy to get this in if you remove the CLI and submit it in separate PR since it may require additional process. We can fix the errors faster this way.
@dguy : Ah, this is interesting.  I was actually under the impression that you are expected to close stores from within your transformers/processors.

I would suggest that we should also update the javadocs of `StateStore`.

Currently, it reads:
```java
    /**
     * Close the storage engine.
     * Note that this function needs to be idempotent since it may be called
     * several times on the same state store.
     */
    void close();
```

This was actually one of the reasons taht led me to believe that you SHOULD close stores in your processors/transformers.

Follow-up question:

> seeing as we re-use state stores across rebalances they should be closed by the Processor.

But, in that case, wouldn't `StateStore#init()` be called again, thus recovering the state store (if need be)?  Or is the problem that `StateStore#init()` would reconstruct the store from scratch?
